ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
And as for its end and destination, it is death, indicated by the saying of the Exalted: "Then He causes him to die and buries him, then when He wills, He resurrects him." And its meaning is that He strips him of his Spirit (Ruh), his hearing, his sight, his knowledge, his power, his sensation, his perception, and his movement, so he returns to being inanimate matter as he was the first time. Nothing remains except the form of his limbs and his image, with no sensation in it nor movement. Then he is placed in the earth and becomes a stinking, filthy corpse, just as he was in the beginning a despised drop of fluid. Then his limbs decay, his parts disintegrate, his bones become hollow, and he becomes scattered remains and fragments. And the worms eat his parts, beginning with his pupils, plucking them out, and his cheeks, cutting them off, and with all his other parts, until he becomes dung in the bellies of the worms and becomes a corpse from which animals flee and which every human finds repulsive and flees from due to the intensity of the stench. And the best of his states is that he returns to what he was and becomes earth from which cups are made and from which buildings are constructed, so he becomes non-existent after having been existent. And it is as if he had not been reaped yesterday, just as he was in his first state a long duration. And would that he remained thus, how excellent it would be if he were left as earth. No, rather He revives him after a long decay to experience severe torment. He emerges from his grave after the gathering of his scattered parts, and he emerges to the terrors of the Resurrection, and he sees a standing Resurrection and a sky split and torn, and an earth changed, and mountains set in motion, and stars falling, and a sun eclipsed, and dark conditions, and harsh, severe angels, and Hellfire blazing, and a Paradise which the criminal looks upon and regrets, and he sees the records.

Rather, it must be in land with water that mixes its water with the land, becoming mud. And to this is the allusion in His saying, the Exalted: 'Then let man look at his food: We poured down water in abundance, then We split the earth in fissures, and caused to grow therein grain, and grapes and fresh vegetation, and olives and date-palms' (Quran 80:24-29). Then air does not move to it by itself, so it needs a wind that moves the air and strikes it with force and violence upon the land until it penetrates into it. And to this is the allusion in His saying, the Exalted: 'And We send the winds fertilizing' (Quran 15:22). And its fertilization is in effecting the coupling between air, water, and land. Then all of that does not benefit you if it is in excessive cold and harsh winter, so you need the heat of spring and summer. Thus, the need of its nourishment for these four has become clear. So look at what each one needs: water needs to flow to the land of cultivation from seas, springs, rivers, and canals. So look how Allah created the seas, gushed forth the springs, and made rivers flow from them. Then the land may be elevated, and waters do not rise to it, so look how Allah, the Exalted, created the clouds and how He subjected the winds to them to drive them by His permission to the regions of the earth, and they are heavy clouds bearing water. Then look how He sends it pouring down upon the lands in the time of spring and autumn according to the need. And look how He created the mountains as preservers of waters, from which springs gush forth gradually; if they came out all at once, they would flood.
